018package org.opengis.filter;
019
020import java.util.List;
021import java.util.function.Function;
022import org.opengis.util.ScopedName;
023import org.opengis.feature.Feature;
024import org.opengis.annotation.UML;
025import org.opengis.annotation.Classifier;
026import org.opengis.annotation.Stereotype;
027
028import static org.opengis.annotation.Obligation.MANDATORY;
029import static org.opengis.annotation.Specification.ISO_19143;
030
031
032/**
033 * A literal or a named procedure that performs a distinct computation.
034 * An expression can accept zero or more arguments as input and generates a single result.
035 * The arguments themselves are in-turn expressions and shall appear in the order in which
036 * they are defined in the {@code FilterCapabilities}.
037 *
038 * <p>Expressions are applied on objects of type {@code <R>}.
039 * Those objects are typically {@link Feature} instances,
040 * but expressions can also be used with other kind of objects such as coverage's geometry-value pairs.
041 * The value of {@code <? super R>} can be obtained at runtime by a call to {@link #getResourceClass()}.</p>
042 *
043 * <p>Expressions return a value of type {@code <V>}.
044 * Expressions that can be used as {@link Filter} operators shall return a {@link Boolean} result.</p>
045 *
046 * <p>Expressions can be implementation-specific functions.
047 * Each execution environment should provide a list of supported functions
048 * (and the number of arguments they expect) in their {@code FilterCapabilities}.</p>
049 *
050 * @author  Chris Dillard (SYS Technologies)
051 * @author  Justin Deoliveira (The Open Planning Project)
052 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
053 * @version 3.1
054 * @since   3.1
055 *
056 * @param  <R>  the type of resources (e.g. {@link org.opengis.feature.Feature}) used as inputs.
057 * @param  <V>  the type of values computed by the expression.
058 */
059@Classifier(Stereotype.ABSTRACT)
060@UML(identifier="Expression", specification=ISO_19143)
061public interface Expression<R,V> extends Function<R,V> {
062    /**
063     * Returns the name of the function to be called.
064     * The {@linkplain ScopedName#head() head} should identify the defining authority and
065     * the {@linkplain ScopedName#tail() tail} should identify the function.
066     *
067     * <div class="note"><b>Examples:</b>
068     * This might be {@code "foo:cos"} or {@code "foo:atan2"} where {@code "foo"} is
069     * the name or abbreviation of the specification or software defining the function.</div>
070     *
071     * The name can be used to look up the number of required parameters in a {@code FilterCapabilities}.
072     * For the specific meaning of the required parameters, see implementation documentation.
073     *
074     * @return name of the function to be called.
075     */
076    @UML(identifier="Function.name", obligation=MANDATORY, specification=ISO_19143)
077    ScopedName getFunctionName();
078
079    /**
080     * Returns the class of resources expected by this expression. This is the runtime value of the {@code <R>} type,
081     * except that some implementations may accept instances of a more generic type such as {@code Object.class}.
082     * For example {@link Literal} may put no restriction on the resource type because it ignores the given resource.
083     *
084     * <h4>Implementation note</h4>
085     * For some expressions like {@link ValueReference}, the resource class may be an implementation-dependent
086     * hard-coded value. For other expressions, the return value should be assignable to all resource classes
087     * expected by the {@linkplain #getParameters() parameters}.
088     * The type parametrization rules guarantee that at least one such specialized class exists: {@code <R>}.
089     * The behavior of this method is undefined if compile-time type safety was bypassed with unchecked casts,
090     * resulting in possible inconsistencies in the tree of expressions.
091     * The undefined behavior may be throwing an exception or returning {@code null}.
092     *
093     * @return type of resources accepted by this expression.
094     *
095     * @see Filter#getResourceClass()
096     */
097    Class<? super R> getResourceClass();
098
099    /**
100     * Returns the list sub-expressions that will be evaluated to provide the parameters to the function.
101     *
102     * @return the sub-expressions to be evaluated, or an empty list if none.
103     */
104    @UML(identifier="Function.expression", obligation=MANDATORY, specification=ISO_19143)
105    List<Expression<R,?>> getParameters();
106    /*
107     * API design note: the `<R>` parameterized type could be more generic. It could be `<? super R>` instead.
108     * However expressions and filters are often chained, and following a chain of expressions become difficult
109     * if, when asking parameters of parameters, the `<? super R>` type become a kind of `<? super ? super R>`.
110     * The latter is reported by the compiler as `<? super #CAP1>`. Experience with implementation shows that
111     * it is difficult to avoid unsafe cast in such cases.
112     */
113
114    /**
115     * Evaluates the expression value based on the content of the given object.
116     *
117     * @param  input  the object to be evaluated by the expression.
118     *         Can be {@code null} if this expression allows null values.
119     * @return value computed by the expression.
120     * @throws NullPointerException if {@code input} is null and this expression requires non-null values.
121     * @throws InvalidFilterValueException if the expression cannot be applied on the given object.
122     */
123    @Override
124    V apply(R input) throws InvalidFilterValueException;
125
126    /**
127     * Returns an expression doing the same evaluation as this method, but returning results
128     * as values of the specified type. This method can return {@code this} if this expression
129     * is already guaranteed to provide results of the specified type.
130     * Otherwise this method can either (at implementer choice) return a new expression
131     * which will convert values on-the-fly, or throw a {@link ClassCastException}.
132     * Exceptions should be thrown as early as possible (see below for more details).
133     *
134     * <h4>Use case</h4>
135     * This method is useful when a client needs to narrow the type of values provided by an expression.
136     * For example, a method doing spatial operations may accept only expressions returning geometry objects.
137     * A call to {@code expression.toValueType(Geometry.class)} gives a chance to detect early if an expression
138     * is not suitable to spatial operations.
139     *
140     * <h4>Exceptions</h4>
141     * An {@link ClassCastException} should be thrown at this method invocation time if values are known to be
142     * unconvertible to the specified type. But if convertibility can only be determined at {@link #apply(R)}
143     * invocation time, then a {@link ClassCastException} can be thrown at evaluation time.
144     * In this paragraph, "convertible" does not necessarily mean that implementations must be able to copy values
145     * into objects of specified type. It is okay to apply only {@linkplain Class#cast(Object) standard Java casts}.
146     *
147     * @param  <N>     compile-time value of {@code target} type.
148     * @param  target  desired type of expression results.
149     * @return expression doing the same operation this this expression but with results of the specified type.
150     * @throws ClassCastException if the specified type is not a target type supported by implementation.
151     */
152    <N> Expression<R,N> toValueType(Class<N> target);
153}
